All though [[Christianity]] and [[Judaism]] share historical roots, these two religions [[Split of early Christianity and Judaism|diverged profoundly in the first centuries CE]]. [[Christendom]] places emphasis on [[orthodoxy|correct belief (or ''orthodoxy'')]], focusing primarily on response to the [[New Covenant]] that the [[God in Christianity|Christian Triune God]] made through [[Jesus]]. Judaism primarily places emphasis on [[Orthopraxy#Judaism|the right conduct (or ''orthopraxy'')]], focusing primarily on how to respond to the [[Mosaic Covenant]] that the [[God in Judaism|One God of Israel, the God of Abraham, and of Isaac, and of Jacob]], made with the [[Israelites]], as recorded in the [[Torah]] and [[Talmud]].<ref>The Torah also includes instructions for [[Proselytes]] and the Talmud also includes instructions for [[Noachides]], who are not [[children of Israel]], but these are not topics of primary focus for Judaism.</ref>
In other words, Christians obtain [[individual salvation]] from [[original sin]] through [[Repentance (theology)|repentance]] of [[Christian views on sin|sin]] and receiving Jesus Christ as their [[God in Christianity|God]] and [[Redeemer (Christianity)|Savior]] through [[Faith in Christianity|faith]], rituals and [[sacrament]]s, that express their New Covenant with God. Jews individually conduct in accordance with holy scripture and collectively participate in an eternal dialogue with the living [[God of Israel]] through tradition, rituals, [[Jewish prayer|prayers]] and [[Jewish ethics|ethical actions]], that express their nation's covenant with God. Mainstream Christianity worships a [[Trinity|Triune God]] who also is [[Hypostatic union|human]]. Judaism emphasizes - since almost some 4000 years until now - the [[Shema|Oneness of God]] and strictly rejects - since almost some 1800 years until now - the Christian concept of [[God the Son|God in human form]].
